data.title: Faculty & Staff
data.text:
Professor

Deputy Department Head

Rockyview General Hospital

email: tbismar@ucalgary.ca

Dr. Bismar’s research focuses mainly on prostate cancer in two areas; low-intermediate disease whose patients are enrolled in Active surveillance programs with the aim to develop clinical signatures to guide urologist on follow-up protocols, and when to implement definite therapy, thus promoting “Precision Active Surveillance guidelines”. The second area is related to the development of neuroendocrine prostate cancer post hormonal and radiotherapy, where his main objective is to understand the genomic underlying in increased risk for such differentiation post hormonal and radiotherapy.

charbonneau.ucalgary.ca/our-members/our-members/dr-bismar-tarek

Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Pediatrics

Alberta Children's Hospital

phone: 403.955.7386

email: marie-anne.brundler@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

My primary research interest is in placental pathology. In collaboration with clinical teams and basic researchers we aim to get a better understanding of the impact of inflammatory and vascular placental pathologies on pregnancy outcomes, and child and maternal health. Other research interests include the pathology of immune-mediated gastrointestinal and liver disorders in children, and soft tissue tumors and vascular anomalies in children and adolescents.

Associate Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and

Clinical Neurosciences and Oncology

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower - Heritage Research Innovation Centre

phone: 403.944.4755/403.210.6380

email: jawchan@ucalgary.ca

Dr. Chan is a clinician-scientist and an Associate Professor in the Department of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine at the University of Calgary. As a neuropathologist with a focus in oncology, her clinical expertise is in the diagnostic evaluation of pediatric and adult brain tumours. She has expertise in molecular oncology, and also runs an active research program in brain tumour biology. Her research program applies concepts from developmental neurobiology to further understand mechanisms of disease in brain tumorigenesis. Her lab is examining the intersection of growth factor signaling and intrinsic determinants such as transcription factor function in cell fate determination and proliferation in neural development and cancer.

charbonneau.ucalgary.ca/our-members/our-members/dr-chan-jennifer

Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Medicine

Diagnostic & Scientific Centre

phone: 403.770.3281

email: deirdre.church@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Senior clinician scientist with expertise in medical microbiology and infectious diseases. Current research is focussed on evaluation, development, and implementation of novel non-culture-based methods for detection and surveillance of infectious diseases and bacterial antimicrobial resistance. Application of these methods include population-based studies of the epidemiology of antibiotic resistance, anaerobes causing invasive infections, STIs, and infections in cancer patients. She has published more than 450 peer-reviewed manuscripts, abstracts/conference proceedings, reviews, and book chapters. She has co-authored and been a Section Editor for several major textbooks including Koneman’s Color Atlas and Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 7th Ed.), Clinical Microbiology Procedures Handbook, 3rd, 4th and 5th Ed. and Clinical Laboratory Management, 3rd Ed.

profiles.ucalgary.ca/deirdre-leigh-church

Associate Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Cardiac Sciences

Alberta Children's Hospital

phone: 403-955-2277

email: lawrence.dekoning@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Dr. Lawrence de Koning completed a PhD in Health Research Methodology from McMaster University in 2009, and concurrent postdoctoral fellowships in nutritional epidemiology and clinical chemistry at Harvard University from 2009-2012. He became board certified by the American Board of Clinical Chemistry in 2013 and a fellow of the Canadian Academy of Clinical Biochemistry in 2015. Dr. de Koning works as a pediatric clinical biochemist at Alberta Children’s Hospital, a consultant clinical biochemist for Rockyview General Hospital and has numerous clinical and research interests including biomarkers and epidemiology of pediatric and perinatal conditions, laboratory quality improvement, cardiovascular disease, and nutrition.

Associate Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Medicine

Diagnostic & Scientific Centre

phone: 403.770.3762

email: dan.gregson@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Dr. Gregson is a Medical Microbiologist and Infectious Diseases physician whose current research focuses on the incidence and outcomes of bacteremia. Currently he is involved in two CHIR grants. One is a randomized study on the treatment of S. aureus bacteremia and the other on the management of ESBL E. coli and K. pneumniae bacteremia. In addition to these he is also a PI on a PRHIS grant to standardize the management of S. aureus bacteremia in the province of Alberta.

profiles.ucalgary.ca/daniel-brian-gregson

Assistant Professor

Department of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower

phone: 403-944-4759

martin.hyrcza@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Dr Hyrcza is has completed a combined MD/PhD program at the University of Toronto. His PhD thesis focussed on molecular biology of type I interferon response and its role in HIV progression. He is currently an assistant professor at the University of Calgary with research interests in molecular pathology of head and neck neoplasms such as salivary and lacrimal gland tumours and squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. He is also interested in quality assessment in pathology and in molecular pathology of endocrine tumours.

Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Clinical Neurosciences

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower

phone: 403.944.8849

email: jtjoseph@ucalgary.ca

My current research is mainly focused on the Calgary Brain Bank (CBB). This repository is approved to bank both CNS tissues from patients with neurodegenerative diseases as well as normal controls. Since 2016, the CBB has about 165 donations. These include individuals who died with Alzheimer disease (AD), Parkinson disease (PD) and other Lewy body diseases (LBD), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), corticobasal degeneration (CBD), multisystem atrophy (MSA), frontotemporal dementia (FTD-TDP), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), and multiple sclerosis (MS), along with people who died without known neurological diseases. My research has been to bank and distribute tissues. I also pathologically characterize these donations in significant anatomic detail, to determine the patterns of neuroanatomic degeneration. I have recently focused on autopsies with mixed pathological changes, which increase in aging but can also be present in younger individuals. I have a significant collaboration with Dr. Peter Stys, who has been doing spectral analysis of the different forms of amyloid-like proteins in neurodegenerative diseases. My clinical research also includes working with clinicians on various reports that require pathology.

profiles.ucalgary.ca/jeffrey-t-joseph

Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Physiology & Pharmacology

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower

phone: 403.944.8541

email: mmkelly@ucalgary.ca

Dr Margaret Kelly is a Professor with full Tenure and a Clinician-Scientist in the Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine at the Cumming School of Medicine at the University of Calgary. An Anatomical Pathologist with subspecialization in thoracic pathology, she is the director of the Thoracic Pathology Fellowship program, a member of the Snyder Institute for Chronic Disease and the Alberta Childrens Hospital Research Institute and holds the research Chair in Pediatric Respirology at the University of Calgary. Her research interests include the pathology of asthma, interstitial lung disease and lung cancer. She has received grant funding from the Alberta Heritage Foundation, the Canadian Institute of Health Research and the Canadian Foundation for Innovation and has over 70 refereed publications, including papers in Cell, Nature Medicine, Nature Immunology and the Journal of Clinical Investigation.

profiles.ucalgary.ca/margaret-kelly

Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Pediatrics

Heritage Medical Research Building/Diagnostic & Scientific Centre

phone: 403.210.8652/403.770.3948

email: fkhan@ucalgary.ca

Dr. Khan obtained his Ph.D. in Human Molecular Genetics in India in 2006. He completed his postdoctoral training and clinical fellowship at the University of Calgary. Dr. Khan is a certified Diplomat of the American Board of Histocompatibility and Immunogenetics (ABHI). Dr. Khan has more than 21 years of experience in Transplant Immunology, Cancer Genomics, and Histocompatibility and Immunogenetics. Based on his research, Dr. Khan has published over 105 research articles in scientific journals like Science, Blood, Transplantation, and Blood Advances. Dr. Khan has led the development, validation, and implementation of several advanced clinical molecular diagnostic tests including next-generation sequencing-based comprehensive genomic profiling for myeloid malignancies and solid tumors; Serum-based cytokine profiling, NGS-based COVID-19 variant detection, and post-bone-marrow transplantation engraftment monitoring testing.

profiles.ucalgary.ca/faisal-khan

Professor

Department of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower

phone: 403.944.4232

email: adnan.mansoor@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Dr. Mansoor is a professor and consultant Hematopathologist with the Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine at the University of Calgary. His translational research focuses on leukemia and lymphoma biology through the utilization of various genomic and proteomic platforms. His current work comprises translational studies evaluating oncogenic signaling pathways and their linkage with clinical outcomes in aggressive B-cell lymphoma and the discovery of novel targets for precision medicine. Over the last ten years, he has published over 70 peer-reviewed articles, obtained more than $500,000 in direct peer-reviewed funding as an investigator, and trained over 100 undergraduate, graduate (MSc/Ph.D.), clinical trainees, and post-doctoral scientists. He served as Chair of the examination committee on Pathology with the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada (2012-2022). He is also a member of the review board of leading pathology journals.

Assistant Professor

Department of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower

phone: 403.944.4639

email: ana.nikolic@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Dr. Nikolic completed her doctoral studies focusing on the role of epigenetic factors in glioblastoma cell function and tumour progression, using epigenetic and bioinformatics techniques. Her research interests include leveraging epigenetic techniques to improve our understanding of the spatial and temporal epigenetic remodelling that goes on in this disease, and improving understanding of the links between genetic, epigenetic and functional factors in disease progression.

Assistant Professor

Department of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine

Foothills Medical Centre-McCaig Tower

phone: 403.944.1326

email: erik.nohr@albertahealthservices.ca

Erik Nohr, MD FRCPC DABP, is a Molecular Pathologist with Alberta Precision Laboratories in Calgary, Alberta, and an Assistant Professor with the University of Calgary. His research interests are translational and pertain primarily to clinical applications of molecular testing in neoplasia, including design, optimization, quality assurance (QA), and quality improvement (QI). Clinical molecular test designs led by Dr. Nohr include the Alberta Precision Laboratories Pan-Solid Tumor Fusion RNA NGS panel, Lung Fusion RNA NGS panel, and ASXL1 Fragment Analysis assay. QA/QI projects include comparison of liquid cytology samples to FFPE tissue for predictive biomarker testing for patients with metastatic lung cancer, and performance comparison of multiplex fusion detection platforms for sarcoma diagnosis.

Professor and Department Head

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and

Medicine, and Microbiology, Immunology & Infectious Diseases

Diagnostic & Scientific Centre

phone: 403.770.3578

email: drpillai@ucalgary.ca

Dr. Pillai is Professor and Head of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine, with adjunct appointments in Medicine and Microbiology (MIID) at the University of Calgary. He practices in both Medical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases. His research interests comprise (i) translational studies evaluating cost-effectiveness and outcomes of new diagnostic tests; (ii) developing point-of-care and near-patient diagnostic technology for application in resource-limited settings internationally and (iii) understanding the pathogenesis of infectious diseases using 'omics' approaches. He has published over 130 peer-reviewed articles, obtained over $5 million in direct peer-reviewed funding as a principal investigator and over $10 million in overall funding over the last 10 years from Tri-Council and other sources, and trained over 30 undergraduate, graduate (MSc/PhD), clinical trainees, and post-doctoral scientists in his laboratory. He was recently named 2021 Peak Scholar at the University of Calgary and Fellows of the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) in 2023 . He has served on Editorial Boards of leading journals of IDSA and American Society for Microbiology (ASM) and several international grant review panels. Technology developed in his laboratory has resulted in local commercialization activity including a start-up company in Calgary.

Professor

Departments of Pathology & Laboratory Medicine and Microbiology and

Immunology & Infectious Diseases

Diagnostic & Scientific Centre

phone: 403.770.3573

email: johann.pitout@albertaprecisionlabs.ca

Dr Pitout is a Professor at the Cummings Medical School, University of Calgary and Medical Microbiologist at Dynalife Laboratories Calgary, Alberta, Canada. His main research interests are resistance to antimicrobial agents among Gram-negative bacteria especially the laboratory detection, characterization, molecular epidemiology, and evolution of bacteria with -lactamases. He has been involved in near patient testing, population-based studies, and the roles of MDR clones and plasmids among bacteria producing the extended-spectrum -lactamases and carbapenemases. Dr Pitout has been tracking successful MDR clones locally and globally. More recent research projects involve the underlying reasons for the success of such clones and ways to predict the next global MDR clone. He is an Editor for Emerging Infectious Diseases and Clinical Microbiology Reviews and serves on the Editorial boards of Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Journal of Clinical Microbiology and Diagnostic Microbiology and Infectious Diseases. He has published over 200 peer reviewed manuscripts in this field.

profiles.ucalgary.ca/johann-david-daniel-pitout
